_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing
Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Ventura Coastal - Tipton has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Ventura Coastal - Tipton, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Ventura Coastal - Tipton has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                 | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)

P1 - South System              Anhydrous Ammonia                 13,000

P2 - ATF System                Anhydrous Ammonia                 18,000

P3 - COP System                Anhydrous Ammonia                  3,300



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has m

any policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



Ventura Coastal Tipton operates a citrus juice processing facility in Tipton, CA. The facility has three (3) ammonia refrigeration systems which are referred to as:



Process 1 - South System

Process 2 - ATF System

Process 3 - COP System



Each system provides refrigeration capacity to the following area/components:



South System

Freezer with (4) Evaporators

Oil Mill with (1) Air Handling Unit

Loading Dock with (1) Evaporator

(4) Juice Processing Towers

Orange Juice Glycol Chiller (S&T)

Lemon Glycol Pre-Chiller (P&F)

Permeate Glycol Chiller (P&F)

(2) Cold Wall Tank Room Chillers (P&F)

(9) Cold Wall Tanks

(2) Essence Tanks

(1) Silo



ATF System

Feldmeier Chiller

Juice Chiller

(2) Penthouse Evaporators

Slurry Ice Generator

Glycol Chiller

(10) Silos



COP System

Loading Dock with (1) Evaporator

Cold Storage Room with (2) Evaporators

2,000 Gallon Orange Oil Tank

2,000 Gallon Lemon Oil Tank

5,000 Gallon Oil Tank



The systems utilize a combination of liquid recirculation, flooded, and direct expansion (DX) operation. 



The South System primarily utilizes liquid recirculation (pumped overfeed). The South Silo, Lemon Essence Tank, Orange Essence Tank, Lemon Glycol Pre-Chiller, Permeate Glycol Chiller, and Orange Juice Glycol Chiller configured for flooded operation.



The ATF System exclusively utilizes liquid recirculation (pumped overfeed). The S&T Juice Chiller and Fe

ldmeier Chiller or the lone exceptions which are configured for flooded operation.



The COP System utilizes liquid recirculation for the three (3) oil tanks and direct expansion for the three (3) evaporators.

Each system is equipped with a machinery room/area which houses the following equipment:

South Machinery Area

(2) Screw Compressors

(1) Permeate Chiller and Accumulator

(1) Lemon Glycol Pre-Chiller and Accumulator

(1) Orange Juice Glycol Chiller

(1) Recirculator with (2) integral pumps (directly outside machinery area)

ATF Machinery Room

(3) Screw Compressors

(1) Juice Chiller

(1) Subcooler

(1) Glycol Chiller

(1) Auto Purger

(1) Emergency Pressure Control Valve

(1) Recirculator with (2) integral pumps

COP Machinery Room

(2) High Stage Screw Compressors

(2) Low Stage Screw Compressors

(1) Intercooler

(1) Recirculator with (2) integral ammonia pumps



The flooded portions of the systems operate as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each component configured for flooded operation, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator. From the accumulator, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator. From the accumulator, ammonia is piped to the recirculator or the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



The pumped overfeed system portion of the systems operate as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a liquid feed solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator. From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valv

e and into evaporator.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver. 



Each system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.

 

The COP and ATF Systems at Ventura Coastal Tipton are connected by a high pressure liquid pipe and also share an ammonia diffusion tank and the manifold piping. According to RMP/PSM/CalARP regulation these two systems are a single process. The South System consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping, but is not connected to either the ATF or COP System.  As such, the three refrigeration systems at Ventura Coastal Tipton are treated as two independent processes. 



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Ventura Coastal - Tipton has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of a

n accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration processes at the Ventura Coastal - Tipton facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 34,300 (LBS). It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration processes and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Ventura Coastal - Tipton has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Ventura Coastal - Tipton's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emerg

ency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Ventura Coastal - Tipton has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Ventura Coastal - Tipton continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Ventura Coastal - Tipton's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Ventura Coastal - Tipton's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Ventura Coastal - Tipton has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Ve

ntura Coastal - Tipton has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Ventura Coastal - Tipton now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Ventura Coastal - Tipton employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Ventura Coastal - Tipton will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
